column1: Before 5 August 2019, will the president submit to Congress a bill for implementation of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA)?
column6: ['Economic Policy', 'Foreign Policy']
No signs it's even in a fit state to be submitted
White House reportedly not sending to congress before September 1st.
No! Because it’s trump.
I believe Trump is out of time with this and will wanna save it for a campaign issue in the fall, so he’s likely to delay it as long as possible.
It seems highly unlikely at this point.

Not enough progress to meet the closing date. The bill submission is hampered by rules that allow amendments after a limited period of time after the submission to Congress. GOP more likely to withhold the submission until agreements on changes are negotiated, preventing the Dems from voting on amendments to the bill. https://www.conservativedailynews.com/2019/06/current-state-of-the-usmca-trade-agreement/
Only Senate in session from now till 5-Aug-2019. House not in session.

There is too much contention in congress right now, and the President is not encouraging bipartisanship so I doubt he'd feel confident enough to try getting his pet project through. But, this is a highly unpredictable personality so anything could happen.
ETC
Initial Impression:

Implementation of the deal is currently not in Trumps interest therefore unlikely. Trump benefits from uncertainty in this field as it allows him Tom put pressure on Mexico in the border crisis. He can also use trade questions in his reelection ralleys.

distract
updating: After September

Not likely. Trump still has some fight in him. Although Mexico has been making the right noises, the most recent meeting where Trump came away & lied about getting some new concessions show that the 2 countries are still far apart from any agreement.

10 days to go. There's no evident reason to move any faster than the current September 1 deadline, and reports still indicate that not all issues within the Republican party have been ironed out. > "U.S. Chamber of Commerce CEO Tom Donohue on Thursday said “extraordinary progress” with is being made with Democrats on the USMCA and aside from a “number of adjustments” will be “fixed by the September timeframe.”"^1
Passage of time
the incompetence of the white house, continued blackmailing of the Mexican government to limit migrants
Too many other distractions, and this does not feed his re-election agenda at this time.
Very unlikely in the short space of time left
Not much chance within this time frame. The budget process is a higher priority
The President id getting more defensive

Free trade is a hallmark of the Democrats so even though this deal probably isn't as good for the US as NAFTA, I think at least enough Democrats to insure a majority can be swayed. The Republicans seem to be unable to handle Trump and will probably just vote in favour

US democrats unconvinced that labour laws are robust enough as part of USMCA. Encouraging talks about how the deal is critical from all 3 country leaders but US likely to stall progress momentarily due to internal political dissentions Trump/ Democrats.
Trump is stalling on this because he hopes that it will make him look good if he can get a deal very close to the election.

Political leverage would seem to be better for president to wait until closer to elections with the distractions and everything else going on can blame dems for not passing anything quickly and if economic depression it can all be because congress was too slow.
Intuition
The information given
There are two main reasons for not doing this at this time.
Trump doesn't yet have the confidence to get it through Congress.
US House continues to demand changes to the agreement: https://www.agri-pulse.com/articles/12420-fate-of-usmca-hinges-on-trump-and-pelosi-agreement
Chaos in US government will get in the way
Not that likely in that timeframe
Pure guess
Interest
Summer doldrums and he's now got major problems with passing any legislation through the Houses.
Really!
Poor international relations and summer months so unlikely to happen before that date

-Only 13 working days until the August recess (which begins the 8/5), so even if it is submitted it won't pass before then—especially given democratic opposition. It can still be ratified in September. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-mexico-canada/trump-presses-for-usmca-passage-as-lighthizer-lawmakers-prepare-to-meet-idUSKCN1UA1YZ
July 16 no bill introduced.
Not enough time and White house is in disarray.

Hard to predict Trump. However, If an important bill like USMCA does not pass would be a blow on D. trump aspirations to a second term in the oval office. Definitely, I don't believe he would would implement such a bill before the elections

Blumenauer last week said there was “no way” a vote would be possible before the August recess, but that Congress would continue to work on it in the autumn. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-mexico/mexico-and-us-try-new-trade-fix-to-win-over-democrats-official-idUSKCN1U01Y4

No one ever lost a bet underestimating Trump's competence, only showmanship. this isn't a showmanship issue. I'm still working on creating or finding a concise definition of "showmanship" or perhaps another term for his "Alkibiadian" style.
Basing this on the same news as everyone else today.
White House is likely to send USMCA trade deal to Congress after Sept. 1, sources say https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/10/trump-white-house-likely-to-send-usmca-trade-deal-to-congress-after-sept-1.html

According to the most recent news, the White House is most likely to send a USMCA bill to Congress until after Sept. 1, though the article does still give lip service to the idea that the bill could be sent to Congress as early as this week: https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/10/trump-white-house-likely-to-send-usmca-trade-deal-to-congress-after-sept-1.html
Trump is moving away from an anarchistic mode to a more cooperative mode.

Because turmoil in economics and with Mexico in particular plays well to his base.

Lack of coverage of talks and focus has shifted from Mexico back to China and North Korea.

With a lot changes occurring within the country and the President's interest in wanting to run for re-election, it seems less likely that it will be submitted before August. It is more likely that it will be submitted after August.
The odds are he has already forgotten this issue. It isn't closely related to the border wall, which is the whole story of everything south of the Rio Grande in his mind, a term one uses advisedly.
